text: when it's almost 30 degrees on a bright
summer's day in Sydney the ocean is a
magnet for swimmers but inside these
inviting waters lies one of Australia's
most dangerous natural hazards rip
currents are powerful channels of water
that can drag the unwitting far out to
sea knowing how they work could save
your life oh it has we guess sir that
they are we're way to me
to swim into it as heard but I'm not
sure this is Tama Rama Beach it's one of
the most dangerous in Australia because
of what's lurking beneath this very
inviting water Rob Brander is from the
University of New South Wales he's an
authority on rip currents Rob when we
look out at this perfect looking water
where exactly is the rig so here we've
got all these waves breaking all that
white water coming in it piles up along
the beach and then it comes along and it
goes out right behind us and that green
gap you can see behind me is your rip
current what happens is people going for
a swim they might not know it rips are
they get in deep water they lose their
footing and if they're in the rip the
rip is just like a river and it's taking
you away now you don't feel anything
because you're just going with the flow
but when you look back at the beach and
it's suddenly miles away
that's scary a lot of people aren't very
good at spotting rips and a lot of
people don't know what they are so we
put in this harmless purple dye that is
really a powerful contrast with the
ocean and you put it in literally
knee-deep in the rip and it slowly goes
into the rip and then it goes out very
quickly and people can see just how fast
and just how far these rips take them
and they can take you out 50 100 metres
in less than a minute and for a lot of
people that's an eye-opener they had no
idea there were things in the ocean that
could do that people don't seem to
appreciate the severity of this hazard
but over the long term the fatalities by
rips out strips all those other natural
hazards in Australia the latest figures
show that rip currents kill more than 20
people in Australia each year more than
the combined annual average for
bushfires cyclones floods and shark
attacks most victims are overcome by
panic and fatigue the advice try to stay
calm floats with the current and signal
for help Phil Mercer BBC News at
tamarama beach in Sydney
